The model breaks down at the top of the curve, though. I was added to the IQ baseline reference group by the Tavistock Clinic during the extension of IQ testing to kids in the 60s, but they never told me why they were so interested. My only takeaway was that I could never test again, which is normal maths, it results in an indeterminate calculation (the denominator is the product of the difference between the test subject and every member of the baseline group, so Me-Me=0 wipes out the rest). That's fair for a can of beans, not so for a human being, however much they resemble Mr Bean. He's funny because he's not neurotypical, and that's pure prejudice, in passing. I was born the way I am. The medics had a duty to tell me of their findings, but were so excited by me turning up by accident in a valid baseline cohort they likely forgot. Must have been like finding a mermaid in the catch of a North Sea trawler!
When some really high performer comes along, similar issues appear: they have no measure to be compared to, so either they're given 163, the top marker, or an imputation's made, which isn't objective. I know my original score now, because you decline as you age: Me(60) < Me(12), so I could test, scoring 153-4, implying mid-160s at peak. So, who's in that bracket in the group I'm part of? As you'd expect, not many, just 2, both 163: I wonder who the first one was? So statistically, nobody was smarter, in reality, maybe a dozen were. It's an approximation. Is there corroboration? Yes, the team I was part of won the 2012 Nobel Peace Prize. I wasn't a spear-carrier, either, the major reason given was my work, recognised when I was detailed off to welcome the Eastern European diplomats on the first morning on their pathway into Europe - I'd given the heads-up on the imminent implosion of the Iron Curtain. Also, the only hard data I had from the Tavistock allows me to perform the pre-Binet calculation, based on the General Knowledge test used in the cohort acceptance profiling: I scored GK14 aged 8y6m, 14/8.5=165%. I'm not the first in the family to have been on a Nobel Prize team, either.
My CV isn't credible as a result. Tough. I've done things of legend, made things happen which didn't happen of their own accord. Led the team which restabilised the Albanian economy after the pyramid banking crash in 1997, done the pathfinding to Malta's accession to the EU, completed Gandhi's work, and much more. I don't claim the credit, because my diagnosis includes observed hyperperception, I'm a seer medium, whih means I credit the Almighty, it being very hard not to score when all the opposition's been cleared out of the way for you! That too affects the statistics, having a thumb on the scales. As the Koestler Institute's discovered, it's not a constant, so can't be factored into the equations, with the possible extension of the probability of the improbable implicit in the Poisson distribution as an influence on cusp events in chaos theory forming an exception. The Binomial's not the only model.

So the answer is actually very close to just the percentage of positive reviews.
It gets closer the higher the amount of total reviews is, with a high confidence (>90%) starting somewhere between 10-100 reviews.
At 0 reviews your chance is 50%.
At 1 reviews you have a ~33% chance of not having a positive experience even if all reviews are positive.
At 2 reviews you have a ~25% chance of not having a positive experience even if all reviews are positive.
At 5 reviews you have a ~15% chance of not having a positive experience even if all reviews are positive.
At 10 reviews you have a ~10% chance of not having a positive experience even if all reviews are positive.
At 20 reviews you have a ~5% chance of not having a positive experience even if all reviews are positive.
At 100 reviews you have ~1% chance of not having a positive experience even if all reviews are positive.

You want to know the probability of at least x visitors to your channel given some time period. The obvious choice in distributions is the Poisson distribution which depends only on one parameter, λ, which is the average number of occurrences per interval. We want to estimate this parameter using Maximum Likelihood Estimation.

"someone with a true perfect success rate would never have those two negative reviews" -- this is assuming that the negative reviews reflected a failure on the part of the provider, but people leave bad reviews all the time for reasons beyond the provider's control.

Furthermore, there's an effect with online reviews where bad experience self-select to review the product or service more frequently than average experiences and extreme positive reviews tend to self-select more than average, but less than negative experiences. This generally gets into the problem of poor sampling and manipulation of the metric. Unless the review is mandatory the bimodal 1 and 5 star review distribution seems to reign. Then there are methods that are used by app developers to prompt first to see if the user had a positive experience, if so, ask them to review it, and if not, ask them to provide feedback (but crucially not link them to the reviews)

This is a great example of the limitations of math models. The calculations are interesting and flawless, yet the model is clueless about how the world works (i.e. fake reviews) and thus useless in practice.

How I decide which seller quickly: Most sites break down their 5 Star review systems in detail. Look At the 1 stars.

Seller A has 300 Reviews, 285 at 5 Stars and 15 at 1 or 2 Stars, Around 96%.
Seller B has 100 reviews, 50 at 5 Stars, 50 at 4 Stars, Around 95%.


In this scenario, Seller B is better.

Seller B has a smaller total percentage because of customers who left 4 Stars. An overall positive review but it turns out the product wasn't right for them.
Seller A has a larger total percentage because they're terrible, getting exclusively 1 or 2 Star reviews, but buying bulk 5 Star reviews by botnets from Kazakhstan

If a seller's reviews look like a binomial distribution over the 5 different star ratings, then you can trust the ratings are fair, whatever the average turns out to be.
If a seller's reviews are extremely divisive, people either love or hate their products, they're likely terrible, and buying good reviews on the black market.

I NEVER trust an ebay seller with 90% - 98% unless their less than perfect score is driven entirely by 4 and 3 star reviews. And I generally just don't buy from sellers with exactly 99%, they're almost always driven by botnets with almost exactly 99 identical "A++++++++ Seller" Reviews for every 1 Star "I'm a real person and I hated my experience with this company".

Nice video, but reviews aren't independent from each other. People tend to 'downvote' and 'upvote' products they dislike or like. At the end of the day a rating with more scores taken into account might be seemingly more reliable, coming from 'more sources'. More scores will generally average out a score more. However, a rating with less scores will be less 'contaminated' with social behavioral crap, but simultaneously have single votes weigh heavier. It's actually why neither score is mathematically better at all. It's flawed thinking. This is the first I've ever seen this problem described anywhere online. I independently came up with an almost identical problem, and derived its solution, many years ago.

Assume we have an unfair coin whose odds of flipping heads is x, where x is randomly chosen with uniform distribution from 0 to 1. We then flip that coin F1 times, resulting in H1 heads and T1 tails (but we do not know the exact value of x).

Given that above information, if we were to then plan on flipping the coin another F2 times, then what is the probability that we will flip H2 heads and T2 tails in those additional F2 flips?

I determined that the answer was (F1+1)!F2!/(F1+F2+1)! * (H1+H2)!/H1!/H2! * (T1+T2)!/T1!/T2!

As I recall, I derived this answer using calculus, but I always felt there was almost certainly a more intuitive and simple explanation for the resulting formula. Perhaps someone could explain in a clear way why the above formula works.

You're implicitly assuming that reviews are valid here. That's a dangerous assumption to make. There's so many fake reviews on amazon that any raw/unfiltered analysis like this is almost meaningless.

Electronics, cosmetics, and batteries have gargantuan problems with counterfeit items on amazon. There are literally tens of thousands of listings for batteries that don't actually exist, and there are thousands of listings for SD cards that have hacked firmware on tiny drives. They store the first couple gigs of data so that you don't realize it's counterfeit until after the return window, but anything past that is simply discarded. They show up on your computer as a large drive, but they aren't. Cosmetics? Hey, if you're fine rubbing animal feces on your face, have at it.

Don't believe me? Punch "18650 battery" into amazon. You'll struggle to find real listings. Anything listed above 3500-3600mAh is certified fake. Nobody is actually making 4000mAh batteries, let alone 9900. Every single one of those is a resleeved, often used, often non protected cell, and the vast majority of them are inundated with dozens of fake positive reviews.

A quick formula to find a number choose a number is nCr = n! / r! * (n - r)!

n is the total number, r is the number you’re choosing. So in 50 choose 48 it would look like 50!/48!*2!

Using Amazon reviews makes for a great example problem. In practice, however, the reviews are likely neither independent nor identically distributed.


For independence, you might end up seeing a chain of poor reviews that corresponds to a change in the manufacturing process of a product of something like that. The likelihood of you having a poor experience would then rely more heavily on more recent reviews.


For identical distribution, you just can't assume that each person would get the same service and then leave the same rating. The rating distribution changes depending on the reviewer.


That being said, the effects of the non-independence and non-identical distribution properties may be pretty negligible, and we may be able to assume IID for amazon reviews. Maybe someone has a large dataset of amazon reviews and can try to test that out?
This doesn't account for sybil attacks and fake reviews

I think I will deal with this problem like this:


We assume each seller as a Bernoulli random variable with probability p of getting a good review, and each review is independent (which is not the case in reality). Given a sequence of n reviews X_1, ..., X_n, we can define the likelihood of this sequence given p as L(X_1, X_2, ..., X_n | p) = \prod_{i=1}^n p(X_i | p). The specific value of p that maximizes function L, denoted as p^ (p-hat), is the MLE (aka. Maximum Likelihood Estimator) of p. We can compute MLE using calculus techniques (derivative of L = 0 and second derivative of L < 0).


Of course, MLE is not always the best estimator, we can determine whether an estimator is biased by testing whether E[estimator] = actual parameter. It is not biased if they are equal, and vice versa.


To get a more practical view of the estimation, we can construct the confidence interval of the estimation. By central limit theorem, the distribution of the sum of n independent identically distributed random variables is normal as n approaches infinity. If the estimator can be represented as some constant times the sum of the X_1 to X_n, we can construct the x% confidence interval (we usually use x=90, 95, and 99 in reality) by P(actual is within the interval: [E[estimator] - z*stddev(estimator), E[estimator] + z*stddev(estimator)]) = 2\Phi(z) - 1 > x%. Using the standard normal table, we can compute z, and get the interval.

Now if the product had 10 reviews, the approve/disapprove system only increases samples by 2 (20%), while the five star system increases it by 5 (50%). Is it really the case that having a more gradual rating system should undermine smaller samples more? It seems a bit off to me. The pretending that you're doing is equivalent to a uniform prior, which is unjustifiable.  The uniform prior is maybe unintuitively,  **informative**.  An uninformative prior, like the Jeffreys prior or Bernardo's reference prior, corresponds to adding one half the successes and failures.  This is justifiable because the Jeffreys prior is invariant to reparametrization.  After all, the parametrization you chose (probability going from zero to one, rather than say odds from zero to infinity, or log-odds over the reals)  was a completely arbitrary choice.  And it does not make sense for the answer you get to depend on arbitrary choices.

I love Bayesian stats and think they don't see enough use. Years ago, probably a decade at least, I read a simple article about how to build an email spam filter using Bayesian statistics. It seemed pretty straightforward, taking the different words and other information that comes with an email (header information), looking at how often those 'terms' appear in both spam and non-spam (typically called ham) emails to learn the prior probabilities, then using that you can evaluate incoming emails to give it a likelihood of being spam score. I wanted to be able to categorize a large collection of ebooks I had based on their topic, like math, biology, computer science, etc, so I extended it just a bit to get probability scores for being in each category. After feeding it only a few books of each category, it got very good at guessing the category of the books.


Review systems online are a very complicated problem, because all of the existing ones are actively gamed. Any sort of 'rating' or 'evaluation' online is. I've always wondered why they treat reviews in a sort of 'all reviews are created equal' sort of way. If I am looking to buy a book, and I have reviewed/rated a bunch of other books I have previously read, it would seem to me that if the system were setup to heavily weight reviews posted by other people whose reviews of other books most closely matched my own ratings, it would insulate it against gaming. 10,000 glowing reviews written by people who are gigantic fans of books I hate are worth less than a single positive review by someone whose tastes line up closely with my own. But existing review systems don't tend to treat reviews that way at all. Netflixs recommendation system does, and it is remarkably accurate as a result, but it's in a bit of a different context. I would really like to see Amazon do something like this for product reviews, and also the Steam digital distribution platform for PC games would be monumentally benefited by it.

I usually read the lowest reviews to find out what motivated them. If they are issues I find inconsequential to me, such as slow shipping or, in the case of used products (say, books) then slight imperfections may not matter. In other words, if they are based on unmet, unrealistic expectations, I don't pay them any attention. But, if they have to do with product operation, quality or bait & switch, I choose another vendor. Especially when there is no public response from the original supplier. I give starting companies with low reviews a chance if they have no serious infractions. Everybody needs to start somewhere and the practice of only buying from sellers with a lot of reviews only encourages false reviews. Another tactic I employ before buying from a newbie is to ask a prepurchase question (doesn't matter what the question is about, the more mundanne is probably better) and use the speed and thoughtfulness of response to help me gauge the likelihood of a good overall transaction. If the seller is really slow, unapologetic, and especially curt in their response, I'll pass. I figure I've given you an opportunity normally not available to online suppliers (the opportunity to interact with your customer) and you've taken the single most desired aspect of sales and thrown it in my face, then you don't deserve my business. Sellers, remember: buyers ALWAYS have a choice. Always. If you want their business, act like it at every point of the transaction. Want to know the best way to communicate with customers? Go wait tables in a decent restaurant for a while. There is no better, immediate, and measurable response to your service and communication skills than the tips you receive. In my youth, I knew many servers who blamed their shitty tips on shitty customers (and that happens, for sure) but if they're ALL shitty tips, it's not the customers. You'd be surprised how much difference just the genuine willingness to make a good experience for the customer can vastly improve their impression of you, even when stuff beyond your control goes wrong. But the opposite is also true: be a turd and they'll hold you responsible for everything, especially stuff that's out of your control.

Here's the problem though. At least for books, I've observed that the reviews are really subjective. Some people give a 1 star review, just for the sake of it. Others give 1 star, because they expected something else, rather than because the content in the book is good. This is especially true for misguided students, who mistakenly buy an advanced math book for graduates, rather for beginners. Or machine learning coders, who are just looking for coding books, rather than the real math behind machine learning. A third type of review is about the quality and delivery. When I look for reviews, I am mostly interested about the content and quality, not that you had a bad time with delivery, or because you can't do basic research about the shit you're planning to buy. Such reviews in my opinion are useless, but that's just it. It's a matter of opinion. So this probabilistic model may serve as a nice initial heuristic for your decision, but you should ALWAYS look through the reviews and filter the meaningless bullshit afterwards before buying.

3:12 "Assume that each seller has some underlying probable success rate." This position, that "the probabilities are out there in the world, and it is the job of the scientist to learn what they are" leads to a world of pain, in my experience. And not just my personal experience. For example, you would want a machine learning system to be able to suggest to suppliers optimal ways in which they could improve their service, or improve their review rating, which are two distinct things. Or in terms of public health, you would want to be able to reduce the avoidable coronavirus fatalities which entails building a better model of the causes of coronavirus deaths, and you would want to optimise the data sets you collect to achieve that goal. Thinking about the death rate of people infected with coronavirus as an "objective probability" out there to be discovered makes this a hard problem! The truth is that these probabilities are all conditioned on a certain degree of ignorance about what is really going on "out there", and it is that ignorance we should be exploring. More precisely it is the structure of that ignorance that we are interested in.

In the context of Amazon, unfortunately a lot of the assumptions is broken.
1) Virtually all listings are seeded with some number of fake positive reviews (say N). So instead of formula (p + 1) / (p + n + 2) one should use (min(p - N, 0) + 1) / (min (p - N, 0) + n + 2)


2) Listings are routinely repurposed to other items.


3) Accounts are often sold and new manufacturer starts selling under the original brand name.

Great vid!  I'm looking forward to Part 2, because I've had to explain Laplace Smoothing to several rooms full of engineers over the years.  There's a tacit assumption in there, that all hypothetical values of the underlying probability are equally probable, that always catches them by surprise.  It's an assumption/approximation, not a fact.  If x is unknown except that 0<x<1, you can't just say that p(x) is flat, because it's also true that (for example) x^2 is unknown except that 0<x^2<1, and the distributions for x and x^2 can't both be flat.The same is true for any continuous f(x) where f(0)=0 and f(1)=1, so the choice f(x)=x is quite arbitrary.

Real-life is way more complicated. That 10 ratings you see are more than likely bought reviews. It is better to go with more reviews because the chances of all of them being biased are low.
